result.title: Objective
result.description: Reduction of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with urban transportation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Cumulative, direct GHG emission reductions in the urban transport sector compared to BAU scenario over a 20-year period, ktonnes

baseline.comment: 0 ktonnes CO2

target.comment: 608 ktonnes CO2 (direct reduction from BRT demonstrations)

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Cumulative, direct GHG emission reductions from a pilot scheme to modernize the trucking fleet compared to BAU scenario over a 10-year period, ktonnes

baseline.comment: 0 tonnes CO2

target.comment: 5 ktonnes CO2 (direct reduction from truck modernization program)

actual.comment: N/A

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Operational sustainable urban transport system in Punjab Province

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of completed feasibility studies prepared for BRT in Punjab

baseline.comment: No complete feasibility study on BRT is available in Punjab

target.comment: 2 feasibility studies augmented for BRT in Lahore and Rawalpindi/Islamabad.

actual.comment:
CAP approved bidding for the following study and is underway:
Mapping of Environmental and Socio-Economic Survey along the BRT corridor I in Lahore.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of approved integrated BRT implementation plans for selected cities in Punjab Province

baseline.comment: Lack of holistic planning for integrated BRT system in Punjab.

target.comment: 2 approved implementation plans for integrated BRT system in 2 cities of Punjab.

actual.comment:
Government of Punjab has laid down one BRT corridor in Lahore from Shahdara to Gajumatta. The Component Implementing Unit-Punjab PAKSTRAN Project has floated the following consultancy services to integrate land use development along the BRT corridor from Gajjumatta to Shahdara in Lahore and to align feeder routes connecting the said corridor:
1. Mapping of Land use & infrastructure along the BRT Corridore-1 from Gajjumatta to Shahdara in Lahore
2. Survey of public transport deployed on the routes connecting with and running along the BRT Corridore-1from Gajjumatta to Shahdara in Lahore.
Consultancy for study 1 has been completed.
UNDP CAP has approved the case of Study 2 above. Therefore, the study will be initiated shortly after awarding the contract to the respective consultants.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of institutions available for carrying out advanced research and comprehensive planning and management exercise related to sustainable urban transport (SUT)

baseline.comment: No institutional framework available in Punjab province

target.comment: New policy framework proposing & stream-lining the reporting lines, responsibilities and accountability for each relevant agencies (Punjab Government, and other institutions

actual.comment:
MOU has been signed between the Urban Unit, Punjab (CIU-Punjab) and the UET Lahore to establish R&D unit at DTEM, UET Lahore. UET has allocated a room in its Annex Block. CIu-Punjab has completed refurbishing work with the procurement of necessary IT equipments and office furniture. One Research Officer and an Office Boy are on board from May 2015. The remaining vacancies have been re-announced in different national dailies. It is nearly being accomplished.
One week (March 09-13, 2015) Training of Police wardens (includes other City Traffic Police staff as well) on Bus Rapid Transit during the construction phase has been successfully carried out. 30 Police wardens attended this training.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of cities planning to implement BRT systems by Year 3

target.comment: 2 cities in Punjab Province planning BRT

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of operational BRT demo systems by Year 5

target.comment: 1 operational BRT

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of manuals and studies to improve infrastructure design for BRT system

baseline.comment: Existing BRT system in Punjab has deficiencies in its design and construction

target.comment: Govt. of Punjab adopted and implemented at least 3 manuals to improve infrastructure design and allied facilities required for the demonstration BRT system

actual.comment: ToRs have been developed to procure the services in order to prepare the required manuals to improve the demonstration of BRT System in the country.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Cumulative energy savings generated by BRT demonstration by end Year 5, toe

target.comment: 1,000 toe of energy saved from BRT demonstration

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: 2Cumulative GHG reductions from the BRT demos in Lahore- ktonnes CO2

baseline.comment: calculation is available along the existing corridor in Lahore

target.comment: 4. 304 ktonnes CO2 ( direct reduction from BRT demonstrations in Lahore

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Number of operational frameworks and standard operating procedures for increased efficiencies of BRT operations

baseline.comment: Existing BRT system in Punjab has deficiencies in its operations. Also, no emission.

target.comment: Govt. of Punjab adopted and implemented at least 3 SOPs and NEQs to increase efficiencies in BRT operations

actual.comment: ToRs have been developed for preparation of the required documentation to increase efficiencies in BRT operations.

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Number of strategic integrated urban transport plans

baseline.comment: No strategic implementable plans are available in Punjab

target.comment: 1 strategic plan for holistically planned integrated urban transport

actual.comment: ToRs have been developed for hiring of the consultant.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Operational sustainable urban transport system in Sindh Province

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of completed feasibility plans/studies prepared for BRT in Sindh

baseline.comment: 2 feasibilities studies

target.comment: 1 bankable feasibility study

actual.comment: Consultancies were awarded to two firms, namely, IBS and CISCO, to carry out an Institutional Analysis outlining the impacts of stakeholders interests in order to improve living and working conditions along BRT corridor.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of institutions available for carrying out advanced research and comprehensive planning and management exercise related to sustainable urban transport (SUT)

baseline.comment: Multiple entities in an un-coordinated manner are involved in SUT in Sindh

target.comment: 1 New policy framework proposing & stream-lining the reporting lines, responsibilities and accountability for each relevant agencies (Sindh Government and other institutions)

actual.comment: 30 consultative sessions were held with the respective stakeholders in order to propagate the theme of sustainable urban transport. In addition, one week (24th to 28th March 2015) articulated training was held for traffic police, transport officials, Motor vehicle examiners, Transporters and road users.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of strategic integrated urban transport plans

baseline.comment: No strategic implementable plans are available in Sindh

target.comment: 1 strategic plan for holistically planned integrated urban transport

actual.comment: After detailed consultations with GoS, UNDP and PMU, it was decided that Activity Result 2.3.1 (Strategic plan developed including traffic management measures (incorporating parking and street vendors strategy) along with selected BRT route in partnership with ADB) would be carried out by ADB.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of provincial policies for developing sustainable urban transport for Sindh Province

baseline.comment: Lack of comprehensive urban transport policy framework in Sindh

target.comment: 1 approved Sindh provincial policy on sustainable urban transport with associated implementing rules and regulation (IRRs).

actual.comment: CIU-Sindh has organized a consultative workshop on 30th Dec 2014 on Principle guidelines of Sindh Urban Transport Policy. The objective of this consultative workshop was to share aims and objectives of the PAKSTRAN project with relevant stakeholders and discuss the urban transport policy with them. Thus the principle guidelines for Sindh Urban Transport Policy have been prepared and shared with stakeholders for seeking their inputs.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Number of operational frameworks and standard operating procedures for increased efficiencies of BRT operations
Cumulative GHG reductions from the BRT demo in Sindh- ktonnes CO2

baseline.comment: Existing BRT system in Sindh has deficiencies in its operations. Also, no emission calculation is available along the Sindh BRT demonstration

target.comment:
Govt. of Sindh adopted and implemented at least 3 SOPs and NEQs to increase efficiencies in BRT operations
304 ktonnes CO2 (direct reduction from BRT demonstration in Sindh)

actual.comment: After developing TORs and submitting RFPs for approval, Independent ICs would be hired to keep quality assurance according to the UNDP guidelines.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Percent increase in public transit ridership by Year 5

target.comment: 4% increase in public transit ridership

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Cumulative energy savings generated by BRT pilot by end Year 5, toe

target.comment: 490 toe of energy saved from BRT demonstration

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Cumulative GHG reductions from the BRT pilot by end Year 5, tonnes CO2e

target.comment: 10,140 tonnes CO2e reduced by the BRT demonstration

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Number of strategic plans for holistically planned integrated urban transport by Year 5

target.comment: 1 provincial strategic plan for 2 cities

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Number of provincial policies for developing sustainable urban transport for Sindh Province by Year 5

target.comment: 1 provincial policy on developing urban transport

actual.comment: N/A

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Improved energy efficiency in truck freight transport

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of background studies completed to support Trucking Policy implementation by Year 3

target.comment: 10 background studies completed on supporting implementation of Trucking Policy

actual.comment:
CIU-Trucking Team is on board now and office for the component has been established at the Ministry of Communication.
However the Expanded Project Procurement Committee (EPPC) meeting held on July 30,2015 to identify the suitable firms and consultants to conduct the following studies:
a. Stocktaking of studies (already carried out by ENER-CON, National Transport Research Centre (NTRC) and other organizations) on applicable options for energy efficiency for truck freight transport
b. Study on assessment of CO2 emissions from truck freight transport in a Business-As-Usual (BAU) Scenario.
c. Study on assessment of CO2 emissions from truck freight transport in a Low-Carbon (LC) Scenario. And Adv. for carrying out the study 3.1.2 as per AWP 2015.And approved from all Concerned Quarters.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of implementing rules and regulations (IRRs) and implementing actions formulated and recommended for approval by Year 3

target.comment: 5 implementing rules and regulations

actual.comment:
CIU-Trucking Team is on board now and office for the component has been established at the Ministry of Communication.
However the Expanded Project Procurement Committee (EPPC) meeting held on July 30,2015 to identify the suitable firms and consultants to conduct the following studies:
a. Stocktaking of studies (already carried out by ENER-CON, National Transport Research Centre (NTRC) and other organizations) on applicable options for energy efficiency for truck freight transport
b. Study on assessment of CO2 emissions from truck freight transport in a Business-As-Usual (BAU) Scenario.
c. Study on assessment of CO2 emissions from truck freight transport in a Low-Carbon (LC) Scenario. And Adv. for carrying out the study 3.1.2 as per AWP 2015.And approved from all Concerned Quarters.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of IRRs approved and enforced by Year 3

target.comment: 5 IRRs approved and enforced

actual.comment:
CIU-Trucking Team is on board now and office for the component has been established at the Ministry of Communication.
However the Expanded Project Procurement Committee (EPPC) meeting held on July 30,2015 to identify the suitable firms and consultants to conduct the following studies:
a. Stocktaking of studies (already carried out by ENER-CON, National Transport Research Centre (NTRC) and other organizations) on applicable options for energy efficiency for truck freight transport
b. Study on assessment of CO2 emissions from truck freight transport in a Business-As-Usual (BAU) Scenario.
c. Study on assessment of CO2 emissions from truck freight transport in a Low-Carbon (LC) Scenario. And Adv. for carrying out the study 3.1.2 as per AWP 2015.And approved from all Concerned Quarters.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of trucks involved with pilots to demonstrate energy efficiency objectives of Policy by Year 4

target.comment: 50 trucks involved in pilot

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Cumulative energy savings generated from truck modernization pilots by Year 5, toe

target.comment: 150 toe of energy saved from truck modernization pilots

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Cumulative GHG reductions from a pilot scheme to modernize the trucking fleet-ktonnes CO2

baseline.comment: No emission calculation ids available along the pilot trucking scheme.

target.comment: 5 ktonnes CO2 (direct reduction from truck modernization programme).

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of public-private partnerships for truck modernization by Year 5

target.comment: 3 public-private partnerships

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of trucks planned for involvement in replication of pilots by Year 5

target.comment: 2,000 trucks involved in plans for truck modernization

actual.comment: N/A

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Increased public awareness and institutional capacity on sustainable transport concepts

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of completed awareness raising campaigns programs by Year 5

target.comment: 5 awareness raising campaigns

actual.comment:
1. A media sensitization seminar was organized in Karachi.
2. A policy dialogue Urban Mobility and Transport was organized at National University of Science and Technology (NUST) on April 29, 2015
3. Preparation for the awareness raising campaigns for 2015 has been initiated and the plan is prepared. Pre-event meeting was held at NED University, Karachi. The events will be organized after the summer breaks as Universities are closed.
4. Two awareness raising campaigns organized for higher education institutions (10) in Rawalpindi/ Islamabad and Lahore.
5. A Political Dialogue on Sustainable Urban Transport in Pakistan was organized on February 10, 2015, at Marriott Hotel, Islamabad. The dialogue was attended by representatives of eight major political parties in the country i.e. PPP, PML (N), PML (Q), PTI, MQM, JUI-F, JI, and ANP. The dialogue report is available on the website.
6. A three-days (June 4 to June 6, 2015) awareness raising campaign was organized at Potohar Metro Bus Station, I-9, Islamabad.
7. Detailed framework for SUT-KMD centre prepared. (implementation is in-progress)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total number of cities benefiting from awareness raising campaigns by Year 3

target.comment: 3 cities where awareness raising campaigns have been conducted

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Number of completed training course on strategic urban land use and sustainable urban transport planning (SUTP)
Number of cities and provincial planners and students trained on land use planning (LUP) and SUTP

baseline.comment: No capacities exists in Pakistan regarding urban land use and sustainable urban transport planning

target.comment:
8 training courses of strategic urban land use and sustainable urban transport planning
30 city and provincial planners and students trained
4 educational institutes where LUP and SUTP

actual.comment:
1. Two training workshops were conducted for volunteers in May, 2015 for the Inaugural Ceremony of Rawalpindi-Islamabad-Metro-Bus-Service (RIMBS).
2. A poster competition involving higher education institutions on sustainable transport organized. 49 posters received from 5 institutions of Rawalpindi/ Islamabad and Lahore.
3. Project brochure, notebooks, mugs, posters, project standees, folders, and various other promotional materials developed and disseminated among the relevant stakeholders.
4. The Project website is being regularly maintained. A Facebook page for PAKSTRAN is regularly maintained, which hosts updates about PAKSTRAN activities and news clips regarding the progress on the ongoing Metro Bus System and articles related to sustainable transport. It also has mailing groups for project staff, media and academia. The total number of visit to PAKSTRAN website has reached 6306 by the end of 4th quarter 2014. The PAKSTRAN pages on social networking sites, i.e., Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Flicker have also been created and being maintained.
5. Newsletter of first two Quarters of 2015 is almost ready to be distributed.
6. A comprehensive Capacity Development Plan for the target groups in Punjab and Sindh developed through a consultative process.
7. A training course on Carbon Finance with a specific focus on transport organized for 29 relevant institutions in which trained 49 people.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of city and provincial planners and students trained on LUP and SUTP by Year 5

target.comment: 30 city and provincial planners and students trained

actual.comment:
1. Two training workshops were conducted for volunteers in May, 2015 for the Inaugural Ceremony of Rawalpindi-Islamabad-Metro-Bus-Service (RIMBS).
2. A poster competition involving higher education institutions on sustainable transport organized. 49 posters received from 5 institutions of Rawalpindi/ Islamabad and Lahore.
3. Project brochure, notebooks, mugs, posters, project standees, folders, and various other promotional materials developed and disseminated among the relevant stakeholders.
4. The Project website is being regularly maintained. A Facebook page for PAKSTRAN is regularly maintained, which hosts updates about PAKSTRAN activities and news clips regarding the progress on the ongoing Metro Bus System and articles related to sustainable transport. It also has mailing groups for project staff, media and academia. The total number of visit to PAKSTRAN website has reached 6306 by the end of 4th quarter 2014. The PAKSTRAN pages on social networking sites, i.e., Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Flicker have also been created and being maintained.
5. Newsletter of first two Quarters of 2015 is almost ready to be distributed.
6. A comprehensive Capacity Development Plan for the target groups in Punjab and Sindh developed through a consultative process.
7. A training course on Carbon Finance with a specific focus on transport organized for 29 relevant institutions in which trained 49 people..

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of educational institutes where LUP and SUTP courses are offered by Year 5

target.comment: 4 educational institutes where LUP and SUTP courses offered

actual.comment:
1. Two training workshops were conducted for volunteers in May, 2015 for the Inaugural Ceremony of Rawalpindi-Islamabad-Metro-Bus-Service (RIMBS).
2. A poster competition involving higher education institutions on sustainable transport organized. 49 posters received from 5 institutions of Rawalpindi/ Islamabad and Lahore.
3. Project brochure, notebooks, mugs, posters, project standees, folders, and various other promotional materials developed and disseminated among the relevant stakeholders.
4. The Project website is being regularly maintained. A Facebook page for PAKSTRAN is regularly maintained, which hosts updates about PAKSTRAN activities and news clips regarding the progress on the ongoing Metro Bus System and articles related to sustainable transport. It also has mailing groups for project staff, media and academia. The total number of visit to PAKSTRAN website has reached 6306 by the end of 4th quarter 2014. The PAKSTRAN pages on social networking sites, i.e., Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and Flicker have also been created and being maintained.
5. Newsletter of first two Quarters of 2015 is almost ready to be distributed.
6. A comprehensive Capacity Development Plan for the target groups in Punjab and Sindh developed through a consultative process.
7. A training course on Carbon Finance with a specific focus on transport organized for 29 relevant institutions in which trained 49 people..

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of completed workshops on the implementation of the Trucking Policy by Year 5

target.comment: 8 workshops on Trucking Policy implementation completed

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of completed workshops on integrated BRT development by Year 5

target.comment: 8 workshops on integrated BRT development

actual.comment: N/A

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Number of collaborative arrangements with related initiatives to be built by PMU

baseline.comment: No experiences/collaborative arrangements exist in Pakistan regarding SUT

target.comment: 2 related projects collaborating with PAKSTRAN for lessons learned and knowledge sharing.

actual.comment:
Activity reports of all CIUs timely uploaded on the Project website.
Reports of CIU IUCN prepared and uploaded on the Project website.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Sustainable production of biodiversity goods and services through community ecosystem-based enterprises

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Increase in income for NTFP collectors and villages participating in sustainable NTFP production through CBEs

baseline.comment:
1. Currently NTFP is collected by: nomadic grazers and poorer resident households. Women and children are the main collectors. Contribution of pine nuts and morels to average household income varies from site to site.
Baseline values to be determined in Yr 1 for the following: a) household income from pine nuts and morels in target valleys
b) Community perceptions of value of NTFP and expectations from CBEs in in target valleys

target.comment:
1. a) NTFP collectors obtain 50% more income from sale of sustainably harvested pine nuts and morels to CBEs than from earlier sales to local traders and contractors
b) Community members of least 8/10 CBEs satisfied with CBE performance and willing and able to continue CBE operations

actual.comment: The project is making regular progress in the direction set aside in the target. It is too early to quote any percentage for part a) however, the community members are satisfied with the selection process, initial meetings and tasks performed by CBEs. The open collection of NTFPs in the valleys is banned by the CBEs for outsiders. The value addition trainings have been imparted to collectors and a range of the NTFPs are collected and the information collected from the market on each species has been shared with CBEs. This has encouraged the CBEs to initiate a case with the government not to contract out the collection of NTFPs from GB to any outside contract in lumpsum, which is the routine practice of the government.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. At least 20,000 ha of critical habitat of target high value NTFPs protected for sustainable production of certified NTFPs in project conservancies

baseline.comment: 2. 0 Ha of forest under certified NTFP production

target.comment: 2. At least 5,000 ha of critical habitat of Chilghoza forest and 15,000 ha of other high value target NTFPs in temperate forest in Astore, Kalam and Dir Kohistan protected and under certified production of NTFPs.

actual.comment: The areas for high value target NTFPs are identified in the conservancies, meetings and discussions were held with communities to ensure conservation of the critical habitat through communal decisions. A range of relevant organisations were contacted with the purpose to explore certification for selected species of medicinal an aromatic plants. Finally, FairWild due to its comprehensive certification standard for sustainable collection, equitable distribution and health perspectives, was elected. The Action plan has been developed together with FairWild. The future plans of the project include an agreement with FairWild, visits by the experts to participate in the Business and Biodiversity Round Table BBRT) and visits of the auditors to the field.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Landscape conservation approaches introduced resulting in improved conservation management of selected threatened species and habitats

baseline.comment:
3. Some conservation measures implemented by local communities, but not for the following:
a) Leaves of Taxus wallichiana (CITES Appendix I) harvested ilegally for fodder and as NTFP
b) Morel mushroom collection practices adversely impacts pheasant populations, including globally threatened species (e.g. White crested Kalij), through breakage and collection of pheasant eggs

target.comment:
3. Improved conservation management of at least 1 significant threatened species or natural habitat type each CBE valley:
a) No illegal harvesting of Taxus wallichiana (Himalayan yew, Cites Appendix I) in at least 6/10 CBE areas
b) Collectors in 6/10 CBE areas collect morels later in season to minimize damage to wild pheasant eggs

actual.comment:
Conservation measures agreed with 4 CBEs for imposing ban on illegal collection of all CITES Species including Taxus Walliciana
The morels are collected by CBEs according to the Terms and Conditions agreed with the project including late season, right size and in selected pastures

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Strengthened institutional capacity for landscape conservation and CBE establishment and certified production of NTFPs in Pakistan

baseline.comment:
4. a) Considerable capacity, especially among NGOs, (e.g. RSPN, Sarhad RSP, AKRSP) for social mobilization & establishment of different types of village organizations, including, to a lesser extent, enterprise development Some national capacity for organic certification of agricultural /horticultural products. Little capacity among NGOs or key government agencies / dpeartments (e.g. PFI, KP & GB Forestry Departments & MINFAL) for promoting biodiversity conservation through certified production of NTFP by local communities or for delivering extension services in an integrated rather than sectoral way
b) No agency in Pakistan has experience or training to verify whether NTFP production complies with agreed certification standards

target.comment:
4. a) At least 70% of CBE requests for additional capacity development support and extension services to be established in Year 3 are met satisfactorily by Year 4
b) At least one national body trained (and potentially accredited) to verify NTFP produced under certification scheme

actual.comment:
4 a) The project is in its 2nd year of implementation
b) Several national and provincial bodies including PARC, NARC, Pakistan Forest Institute, NTFP department of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa have been identified for participation in the training program for possibilities of selection/ agreement to act as accreditation bodies under certification schemes.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Market demand for biodiversity friendly non-timber forest products (NTFP) stimulated

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Increased support for sustainable NTFP production use within private sector in Pakistan through (Business and Biodiversity Round Table) BBRT

baseline.comment: 1. No opportunity for private sector to preferentially buy sustainably produced wild NTFP as no certification systems in place

target.comment: 1. At least 3 major herbal industries in Pakistan include reference in their CSR policy to preferential buying of certified NTFP from project areas

actual.comment: The BBRT has membership from major industries and related institutions in the private sector. Two meetings of the forum was held where most of the industries including Herb ion, Hamdarad and Hunza Organics committed to purchase the certified products once available with CBEs as preferential buying of raw material as part of their CSR polices. The industries showed interest in certification schemes and the process as well. The market study was discussed in length and it was found that that the market study is an inbuilt component of the FairWild Certification package. Work has been started on it.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of voluntary NTFP certification systems established

target.comment: 2. Voluntary certification schemes for sustainable production established for at least 2 NTFP including: a) Chilghoza pine nuts; b) Morel mushrooms;

actual.comment: Work is in progress to explore the suitable certification scheme/s and the standard for at least for two species (Morels and Pine nuts) primarily in the European market.The market study was discussed with the consultant hired for the certification schemes. He has submitted his first deliverable and will continue work according to the TORS in the days to come.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of alliances with national & international buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversity-friendly NTFP from project CBEs

target.comment: 3. At least 10 operational alliances with international and national buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversity-friendly NTFP from northern Pakistan

actual.comment: The concept of establishing conservancies alliance was shared with CBEs. The work is under way to create a strong alliance of communities for extended market support to CBEs. Communal alliances will be created by bringing CBEs together so that a consolidate approach towards accessing the market is obtained. Formation of such two alliances are under way each in KP and GB. Furthermore, on the buyers side, individuals and well collective meetings were organised with several companies for exploring the possibilities of forming national and international alliances.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Revised regulatory framework for NTFP collection & trade

baseline.comment: 4. No comprehensive regulatory framework for NTFP collection & trade. A few special rules for some products.

target.comment: 4. A comprehensive regulatory framework for NTPF collection & trade that supports sustainable NTFP production

actual.comment: Currently, there is no mechanism of sustainable harvest of MAPs species except a simple procedure of contracting an outside individual for unmonitored exploitation in the provinces. The existing legislation pertaining to Medicinal and aromatic plants species was reviewed in Gilgit Baltistan(GB) and fresh rules were developed through a broader process of building stakeholder consensus. The draft rules prepared are under broader review of the related institutions, traders and community organisations in GB. The rules will be finalised in the next few months.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Strengthened capacity of local communities to produce and market biodiversity-friendly products

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of conservancy villages & valleys receiving support for CBE development & management

baseline.comment: 1. Conservancy villages have experience of forming new village institutions and understanding of biodiversity conservation & SRU principles & a few have experience of enterprise development, but none have experience of certified sustainable production of NTFP

target.comment: 1. At least 20 villages and 10 valleys receive training on the business and technical skills needed for successful CBE establishment & participation in voluntary certification schemes

actual.comment: Eight CBEs were established and three of them were registered. Necessary training on record keeping and CBEs management were imparted to help them shoulder the responsibility of running CBEs as business entities. The training needs and assessment were completed in the entire project conservancies and training of best practices, of collection, post harvest processing grading, packaging and labelling were imparted in all the conservancies. Furthermore, Training of Trainers (TOT) for the professional staff of Forest departments were completed as extension service providers to CBEs in future.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of operational CBEs with approved business plans participating in voluntary NTFP certification schemes

baseline.comment: 2. All Valleys have Valley Conservation Plans and Valley Conservation Funds. Some have community-based trophy hunting enterprises. There is no community-based certified NTFP production

target.comment: 2. At least 10 CBEs with approved business plans participating in one or more NTFP voluntary certification schemes

actual.comment: CBEs are sensitised through dedicated session for participation in relevant certification scheme for raw material of MAP species

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Community access to relevant technical, financial and market information services for CBE development

baseline.comment: 3. No extension services currently available to communities for biodiversity business planning or sustainable, commercially viable NTFP production

target.comment: 3. A mechanism for coordinated delivery of technical, financial and market advisory services to CBEs in place and being used effectively by CBEs for business planning and development

actual.comment: Dedicated sessions of the CBEs were organised with the government financing mechanism as support to CBEs. The formation of 4 CBEs and one national alliance is progress and will be completed by the end of June 2016. Such Alliances, once in place will provide regular advice on market fluctuation, demand and will link CBEs with the available institutions for technical and financial support to CBEs in the long run. Grants were provided to 8 CBEs as incubator funds for operationalising CBEs. Such grants will also be provided to the National Alliance for better coordination with the market/institutions and extended support to CBEs.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Positive biodiversity linkages strengthened at landscape level through CBE Conservation and Sustainable Resource Use (SRU) agreements

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of specific biodiversity conservation measures successfully implemented by project CBEs at landscape level under their Conservation and SRU Agreements

baseline.comment: 1. Some biodiversity conservation measures are being implemented under Village and Valley Conservation Plans, which will not be duplicated in this project

target.comment: 1. At least 2 specific and quantifiable priority conservation measures included in each of the 10 CBEs Conservation & SRU Agreements and integrated into the relevant Landscape Conservation Plans (LCPs)

actual.comment: Developing Conservation Agreements is a long process. Communities were sensitised for agreements. Lengthy sessions were organised with CBEs and the relevant government institutions to agree on terms of partnership. The project has reached agreement with CBEs on arresting illegal cutting of forests, extending full cooperation to provincial forestry and environment departments, decreasing poaching and putting a ban on illicit and unorganised extraction of MAP species in 6 conservancies. These conservation measures are drafted in the conservation agreements, which will be finalised and signed between the relevant government institutions and the authorised community bodies Conservancy Management Committees/CBEs.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of collaborative forest management initiatives developed and implemented by State Forestry departments and local communities

baseline.comment: 2. Not applicable as there is no collaborative forest management in the country.

target.comment: 2. At least one collaborative forest management developed and under implementation in every conservancy.

actual.comment: Mechanism of collaborative forest management has been discussed and agreed with CBEs. Joint consultations of the project, Forest and Environment departments and CBES in the field is in progress at two demonstration sites each in Astore and Kalam Conservancies for developing Joint Forest management Plans with support from IUCN.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of community-based assessments of CBE performance, including economic and conservation benefits generated

baseline.comment: 3. Not applicable as CBEs do not exist yet. However, there is precedent of such assessments developed through MACP and continued through PMAC in relation to reviews of Valley Conservation Plans by concerned villagers

target.comment: 3. Annual participatory community-based assessments of CBE performance used together with project monitoring and any other assessments to adapt individual CBE management, including implementation of business plan and Conservation & SRU Agreement

actual.comment:
Regular monitoring of the CBEs performance is under way with support from UNDP, the Ministry of Climate Change and the project itself. Capacity building events on CBEs operationalisation and management including administration and financial mechanism were organised.
The project also completed baseline for MAPs species in all conservancies with support from IUCN. IUCN has been asked to initiate work on developing, testing and refining biodiversity monitoring indicators for the project and establishing participatory monitoring systems to be used by communities for assessing resource status, impact of interventions and recording changes for course correction.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Strengthened institutional capacity for scale up and replication of CBEs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of key institutions and agencies with capacity to provide coordinated support to mountain communities wishing to establish CBEs and participate in certified sustainable NTFP production

baseline.comment:
1a) Targeted institutions and agencies have considerable capacity in their sectors/ focus areas but limited expertise in supporting biodiversity-friendly, commercially competitive enterprises
1b) No mechanisms exist for coordinated delivery of extension services
1c) There is no partnership yet and hence no budgetary support for CBE scale up & replication other than through the cofinanciers of this project (MoE/PMAC & UNDP)

target.comment:
1a) Targeted capacity development of at least 8 major partner national organizations/government agencies to support certified NTFP production by CBEs in northern Pakistan, including KP and GB Forest Departments, AKRSP, Sarhad RSP, IUCN, PFI, MINFAL
1b) Mechanism for providing coordinated support to communities agreed and implemented by key partners willing to provide on-going support to communities for CBE development and certified NTFP production
1c) Committed budgetary support from the partnership of organizations to provide capacity development to communities for CBE scale up and replication

actual.comment:
Orientation and sensitisation events were organised for the provincial and national government institutions, rural support programs and relevant industries for extending support to CBEs. Research institutions were engaged through establishing research stations for future support to CBEs. Students are engaged in the specific surveys and scientific assessment of various parents of MAPs species in the field.
The provincial government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Gilgit Baltistan have generously agreed to provide their own moneys from July 2015 onward as co-finaincing from Annual Development Plans. This will help strengthen the ownership of the government agencies and will also augment the project resources for extended support to CBEs and communities at large.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of dedicated follow up activities to systematically analyze, document and disseminate project knowledge and lessons learned regionally, nationally and globally

baseline.comment: 2. No project knowledge or lessons exist as the project has not started implementation

target.comment:
2a) At least one synthesis report summarizing main project achievements and lessons in English and Urdu
2b) Community to community learning facilitated by arranging for non-project villages to visit successful CBEs.
2c) Project knowledge and lessons shared across northern Pakistan through PMAC, the Valley and Conservancy Management Committees AKRSP, Sarhad RSP and AJKRSP
2d) At least one regional conference bringing together local communities, government, NGOs, private sector and other key stakeholders to share project achievements
2e) One national conference organized through the Business & Biodiversity Round Table to share project knowledge & lessons learned with key national stakeholders

actual.comment:
IUCN has been engaged to support the project in these particular activities. Thus a project website has been created and maintained through IUCN. Data on the MAP species, progress and various achievements of the project will be gradually uploaded on the website.
Communal exchange visits, national and regional conferences will be completed by June 2016
